Graphical abstract In this work, heterogeneous acid catalysts based on sulfated iron oxide produced from mining tailings were prepared by different processes, i.e. ammonium sulfate by simple grinding, (NH4)2SO4 aqueous impregnation and sulfuric acid impregnation, all treated at 500 °C. The materials were characterized by Mössbauer and Raman spectroscopies, FTIR, XRD, SEM, pyridine adsorption FTIR and potentiometric titration. The main mineral phases found were hematite and quartz and it was observed a great increase in the acidity of the materials produced due to the presence of sulfate groups. The synthesis with sulfuric acid was the most efficient process due to the formation of a greater amount of dispersed acid sites (density 0.1211 mmol g−1). The materials were used in esterification reactions. Ester production using 5 wt% of catalyst based on acid synthesis, 1:15 oleic acid:methanol molar ratio, 120 °C and 4 h led to conversions of 100%. Keywords Biodiesel Esterification Sulfated iron oxide Acid catalysis Mining waste 1 Introduction Biodiesel is an alternative source to petroleum-derived fuels, once it has compatible properties with petroleum diesel and several advantages, such as its renewable nature, high availability and biodegradability [1,2]. Generally is produced by transesterification reactions, however, it can also be produced by esterification of free fatty acids and an alcohol in the presence of an acid catalyst [3]. Acid homogeneous catalysts usually presents excellent yields for biodiesel production via esterification reaction. However, it usually leads to corrosion problems and difficulty on the products separation [4]. Therefore, the study and development of heterogeneous catalysts with high activity to convert low quality acidic oils is of considerable interest. Potential advantages of this route are elimination of the washing step and more facile separation which reduces the cost and time of the process [5–7]. Some examples of heterogeneous acid catalysts that have been used in esterification reactions are sulfonated carbon [8], ion exchange resins [9], zeolites [10], sulfated oxides [11–14] and supported metals on silica matrices [15]. Sulfated metal oxides are materials that have high acidity and, therefore, have been reported as promising heterogeneous catalysts for biodiesel production via esterification reaction [11]. Among these, the catalysts based on sulfated iron oxides are of great importance because of the efficiency reported by some studies and the abundance of iron oxides [16,17]. Kaur et al. investigated the catalytic performance of different heterogeneous catalysts in the esterification of nonanoic acid with methanol. In this study, the following catalysts were synthesized: zirconia-supported tungstophosphoric acid, sulfated zirconia and sulfated iron oxide. Catalytic activities were compared with ion exchange resins commonly used in esterification. The results showed that all catalysts led to an excellent conversion when compared to the resins and, considering the total cost and catalytic activities, sulfated iron oxide was considered the cheapest and most efficient catalyst among all the catalysts used [11]. An interesting source of iron oxides is the iron ore tailings from mining companies stored in dams which have significant environmental impacts and, since they are large structures, may present potential damages due to their rupture, leakage, infiltration or malfunction [18]. In recent years, there have been two problematic accidents involving tailings dams in Brazil, which have caused great social, environmental and economic impacts for the country [19,20]. To avoid the increasing accumulation of tailings, studies aiming at the use of these materials are of great importance. These iron ore tailings are mainly comprised of iron oxides (30–45% by weight) silica and alumina [21,22]. Iron ore tailings have been extensively studied and used in civil industry as a raw material for the production of ceramics and concretes [23,24]. In addition, a promising application is their use as catalysts, for example, for the treatment of effluents, given the high iron contents observed in the tailings and the iron oxides are efficient catalysts for Fenton and photo-Fenton reactions [25–27]. However, no study has been found in the literature using sulfated iron ore tailings as acid catalysts. Considering the great abundance of the mining tailings and the necessity of their use, in this work, acid heterogeneous catalysts based on sulfated iron oxides were synthesized using a mining waste as iron oxide source. These catalysts were tested in esterification reactions of oleic acid and methanol. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalysts synthesis The iron mining waste was dried for 24 h at 80 °C. A sample of the material was calcined using a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in a horizontal tubular oven at 500 °C for 2 h under air atmosphere, for comparison with the catalysts produced. The pure waste sample was named MUD and the waste sample calcined at 500 °C was named MUD*. The catalysts were prepared using three different processes: 1- Dry synthesis (sample DS): 8.00 g of the waste was mixed with 2.40 g of ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4 – Ecibra) in mortar and pestle for 40 min. 2- Wet synthesis (sample WS): 4.00 g of the waste was added to a solution of 1.20 g of ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4 – Ecibra) and 120 ml of distilled water. The mixture was kept under stirring at 300 rpm at room temperature for 10 min and sonicated for 30 min. Afterwards, the solvent was evaporated and the obtained solid was dried at 80 °C. 3- Acidic synthesis (sample AS): 4.00 g of the waste was added to a solution of 0.50 ml of 95–98% sulfuric acid (H2SO4 95–98% - Anidrol) and 120 ml of distilled water. The mixture was left under stirring (300 rpm) at 85 °C until the solvent evaporated and the obtained solid was dried at 80 °C. The solids obtained were calcined at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in a horizontal tubular oven at 500 °C for 2 h under air atmosphere. Thereafter, the materials were extensively washed with water (until pH ∼ 7) to remove free acid groups and dried at 80 °C. 2.2 Catalysts characterization 57Fe Mössbauer measurements were obtained at room temperature on a constant acceleration transducer with a 57Co/Rh source. XRD analysis was performed in a Shimadzu diffractometer, model XRD-7000 with CuKα radiation (1.5406 Å) and scanning speed of 4° min−1. Raman spectra of the materials were measured using Raman Bruker Senterra spectrometer coupled to an optic microscope (Olympus BX51). The data were acquired using laser 633 nm, 10 scans / 10 s and 0.2 mW of power. FTIR spectra were obtained in a Perkin Elmer, Frontier Single Range-MIR spectrometer, using ATR mode. The spectra were obtained in a spectral range of 4000 to 550 cm−1, resolution of 4 cm−1 and 16 scans. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained in a FEI Quanta 3D microscope equipped with a Silicon Drift Detector. For Energy Dispersive x-ray Scattering (EDS) mappings, 15 kV high voltage, 4.5 spot size and 50 μm objective aperture were used. The catalysts acid properties were determined by pyridine adsorption method. In this test, 10 mg of catalyst were placed in crucibles inside a quartz tube in a furnace and heated to 200 °C, for 2 h, under N2 flow. After cleaning the surface, the pyridine was then introduced, at 50 °C. After the adsorption step, the temperature was raised to 100 °C under N2 flow to remove any physisorbed pyridine on the catalyst surface. Afterwards, the materials were analyzed by infrared spectroscopy in a Perkin Elmer, Frontier Single Range - MIR spectrometer, using ATR mode. The spectra were obtained in a spectral range of 4000 to 550 cm−1, resolution of 4 cm−1 and 16 scans. The materials acidity were determined using potentiometric titration, according to the procedure described by Pizzio et al. [28]. In this procedure, 0.05 g of the catalyst were put in contact with acetonitrile (40 mL) for 24 h. The suspension was then titrated with a 0.025 mol.L−1 solution of n-butylamine in toluene until reaching a constant potential. The electrode potential variation was measured with a Bel pHmeter, model W3B. 2.3 Esterification reactions Esterification reactions of oleic acid and methanol were performed in a sealed glass tube in a sand bath with magnetic stirring. The catalysts based on sulfated iron oxides loads were: 5, 7.5 or 10 wt% in relation to oil weight. The reactions were conducted at 80, 100 and 120 °C for 4 h. The oil:methanol molar ratios used were 1:15, 1:30, 1:45 and 1:60. 2.3.1 Catalyst reuse The reuse tests were carried out under the optimal reaction conditions established by experiments with fresh catalysts. After each reaction, the liquid phase was separated from the catalysts, and the catalysts were directly reused. 2.3.2 Catalyst leaching Leaching tests were also performed under the optimal reaction conditions. For it, the catalyst was transferred to the reaction containing only methanol. The system was maintained under constant stirring and heating. After this period, methanol was removed and transferred to a reaction battle containing only oleic acid, thus proceeding with the reaction. 2.3.3 Products quantification The yield of esterification reactions were analyzed by 1H NMR (RMN Bruker Advance DPX 200), using a calibration curve with mixtures of oleic acid and methyl oleate ranging from 0 to 100%. For quantification, the ratio between the signal in 2.3 referring to the hydrogen of the methylene α-carbonyl group, found in the fatty acid and the methyl ester and the signal at 3.7 ppm, referred to methyl oleate mixtures were used. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The iron mining waste (MUD) used in this work is composed of iron oxide (mainly hematite and goethite) and silicon, with iron content of 44%. The catalysts were prepared by three different routes: grinding with (NH4)2SO4 (dry synthesis DS), impregnation with aqueous (NH4)2SO4 (wet synthesis WS) and impregnation with acid H2SO4 (acid synthesis AS). The materials were also treated at 500 °C under air atmosphere (Fig. 1 ). The iron mining waste were also calcined at 500 °C and characterized (MUD*) to compare the temperature influence in the obtained catalysts. The Mössbauer spectrum of MUD (Fig. 2 ) showed two sextets and a doublet. The sextets have hyperfine parameters consistent with hematite and goethite [29]. The Mössbauer parameters for hematite and goethite are very well known and disseminated in the literature, and the parameters obtained for the material are very similar to them. The doublet is characteristic of paramagnetic Fe3+, likely as in aluminosilicate structures or super paramagnetic iron oxides with very small particle sizes or possible isomorphic substitutions [30–32]. After treatment at 500 °C (MUD*), goethite phase was no more observed in Mössbauer spectrum. Studies have shown that at 350 °C, this phase is decomposed to hematite and water [33]. It can also be observed that Mössbauer spectra were very similar after the different treatments with ammonium sulfate (DS and WS) and sulfuric acid (AS) indicating that these treatments did not cause any significant change in the bulky structure of the iron oxide. Furthermore, the materials hyperfine parameters can be seen in the supplementary material (Table S1). XRD analyses of the obtained materials can be seen on Fig. 3 . MUD diffractogram indicates that this material is composed mainly by hematite (JCDPS Card No. 33-664) and quartz (JCDPS Card No. 46-1045). Moreover, goethite (JCDPS Card No. 29-713) and a small amount of kaolinite (JCDPS Card No. 29-1488) were also present. Kaolinite is a mineral commonly associated with iron mining tailings [34]. After chemical and thermal treatment, diffractograms of samples MUD*, DS, WS, AS, showed only hematite and quartz peaks. The disappearance of the kaolinite peaks on the calcined materials is a consequence of the breakdown of its crystalline structure, which becomes amorphous due to calcination [33]. Raman spectra of materials (Fig. 4 ) showed characteristic bands of hematite vibration modes which were observed with higher intensities. Furthermore, only for pure waste (MUD) it was observed characteristic bands with lower intensities of goethite vibrational modes [35]. These data corroborate the Mössbauer and X-ray diffraction results. It was also expected the presence of a band near 1000 cm−1 in the spectra of the produced catalysts, characteristic of sulfate vibration modes. The absence of this band may be related to the specific low signal intensity in the Raman spectra of the sulfates or to the low stability of the superficial sulfates in the presence of laser beam [36]. FTIR spectra of the materials showed typical absorptions observed in quartz and kaolinite phases (Fig. S1 and Table S2). For the DS, WS and AS materials, the presence of bands related to the sulphate groups was expected, but these are located in the same region as the bands referring to quartz and kaolinite and were not observed. It is believed that the concentration of sulfate in the materials is low and that is why the bands related to their vibrations do not appear or are camouflaged by the presence of more intense bands in the same region. The morphology and particle size of the synthesized materials were also evaluated by SEM images. Fig. 5 shows the images and EDS mapping obtained for the analyzed samples. It was observed heterogeneous materials and a wide particle size distribution. The EDS mapping of samples MUD and MUD* indicated the presence of iron, oxygen, silicon and aluminum. In the catalysts images, no structural changes were observed in relation to the non-sulfated material. However, EDS mapping indicated the presence of iron, oxygen, silicon, aluminum and sulfur. It was also observed that sulfur Kα x-ray excess emission coincides with iron mapping, which may indicate that sulfate groups are associated to iron oxide surfaces. Pyridine adsorption and infrared technique was used to identify the presence of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites in the materials. Theoretically, pyridine adsorbed at Brönsted sites (Py-H+) provides a band at approximately 1540 cm−1, and Lewis sites interaction with pyridine (Py-L) provide a band at approximately 1445 cm−1. The band found at 1490 cm−1 can be related to the adsorbed pyridine simultaneously at Brönsted and Lewis sites [37]. Fig. 6 shows the obtained IR spectra for the materials produced and for the non-sulfated material treated at 500 °C (MUD*). Analyzing the IR spectra of the materials produced, it is observed the absence of the band at 1445 cm−1 referring to the Lewis acidic sites, which indicates that the materials do not present significant Lewis acidity. Comparing the spectrum of the non-sulfated mud and the catalysts produced, it is possible to see the presence of a band at approximately 1540 cm−1, which are related to the Brönsted acid sites present in the materials. The band observed at approximately 1490 cm−1 is theoretically related to the Brönsted and Lewis acid sites simultaneously, however, as the band referring to the Lewis acid sites was not observed, it can be concluded that this band at 1490 cm−1 presents a contribution only of Brönsted acidity. The band at 1620 cm−1 is related to hydroxyls stretching. The results obtained indicate a prevalence of Brönsted acid sites in the produced catalysts. Potentiometric titration measurements with n-butilamine were also performed to determine the surface acid sites. N-butylamine is a strong base and can be adsorbed at acid sites of different types and strength. The strength of the acid sites can be attributed according to the following ranges: E > 100 mV, very strong acid sites; 0 < E <100 mV, strong acid sites; -100 < E < 0 mV, weak acid sites; E <-100 mV, very weak acid sites [28]. It was observed that all the catalysts presented very strong acid sites (E > 100 mV). The AS material presented the highest acid strength and density of acid sites (E =194 mV, 0.1211 mmol g−1), followed by DS (E =155 mV, 0.0248 mmol g−1) and finally the WS (E = 145 mV, 0.0004 mmol g−1). The total number of acid sites obtained by potentiometric titration for the materials produced were low compared to values obtained for similar materials in the literature. The acid sites density of sulfated iron oxide produced by Kaur et al. was 14.4 mmol g−1 [17]. Nuithitikul et al. obtained values of acid sites ranging from 0.96 to 1.20 mmol g−1 for the sulfated iron/tin oxides produced [38]. However, in these studies the material washing did not occur, as in the present work, and it is believed that the washing step is very important to remove acid groups that are not bound and can leach in the reactions. In the literature, the most used techniques to detect the presence of sulfate group or sulfur in sulfated catalysts are FTIR or SEM/EDS [16,17,36]. In this work, despite the presence of sulfate groups had not been observed by X-ray diffraction techniques, infrared spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy and Mössbauer spectroscopy, the EDS mapping measures showed the presence of sulfur in the materials. We believe that it was not possible to detect the presence of sulfate groups by FTIR because of the small amount of these in the materials. Nevertheless, the potentiometric titration and Pyridine adsorption/infrared technique allowed to identify the presence of acidic sites in the materials. 3.2 Esterification reactions The produced materials were tested in the esterification reaction of oleic acid and methanol using a molar ratio of 1:60, 10 wt.% catalyst, 120 °C, 8 h. Fig. 7 shows that all the catalysts showed high conversions under these conditions. For the non-sulfated material (MUD*), the conversion was close to the reaction in the absence of catalyst (blank), indicating that the activity of the materials is directly related to the sulfation process. The reactions were also carried out at different temperatures, i.e. 80, 100 and 120 °C. The conversions varied from 10 to 60% at 80 °C and increased as the reaction temperature increased to 120 °C (Fig. S2). In general, the catalyst AS showed the best results. The effect of oleic acid:methanol molar ratios, i.e. 1:15, 1:30, 1:45 and 1:60, indicated that in general, for DS and WS catalysts, the conversion increased with oleic acid:methanol molar ratio (Figure S3). For the AS material, the molar ratio of 1:15 was already sufficient to achieve a maximum conversion value. Different catalyst concentrations were investigated, i.e. 5, 7.5 and 10 wt.% (Figure S4). For the DS and WS catalysts, a significant increase of the conversion was observed with catalyst load, and the reactions performed with 10% of catalyst showed the best results. For the AS material, the reaction performed with 5% of the catalyst already showed a maximum conversion. Finally, the influence of the reaction time was evaluated. For DS and WS materials, the conditions used were: oleic acid:methanol molar ratio 1:60, 10% catalyst and temperature of 120 °C. An oleic acid:methanol molar ratio of 1:15, 5% catalyst and temperature of 120 °C was used for the AS material. The reaction times tested were 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 h. The conversion results obtained for the catalysts tested at different times are shown in Fig. 8 . For the DS and WS catalysts, it took 8 h to achieve the best conversion values. For the AS material, a much faster kinetics was observed, and a reaction time of 4 h was sufficient to reach a maximum conversion value. Previous studies about the esterification of oleic acid with methanol, using sulfonated carbon species as catalysts, in the same condition used in this work and analyzed by gas chromatography, showed that this reaction is selective for the formation of only one product, methyl oleate [39,40]. This same conclusion was observed in another published papers on the literature [15,41]. Then the selectivity for the formation of biodiesel is this kind of reaction is 100%. Table 1 summarizes the best conditions found for the catalysts. As can be seen, the AS catalysts exhibit optimum performance under much milder conditions than the DS and WS catalysts. By comparing the reaction conditions and the conversion values obtained for the catalysts produced in the present work and the catalysts found in the literature [11,42], it can be concluded that AS material is a promising and efficient catalyst for oleic acid esterification reactions, once it showed optimum conversion results under comparable conditions with literature results. Despite DS and WS catalysts presented good conversion results, drastic reaction conditions were required, being less efficient. Generally, the use of heterogeneous catalysts requires more drastic reaction conditions over homogeneous catalysts [43]. Marchetti et al. studied esterification of free fatty acids using sulfuric acid as a catalyst and achieved conversion values of 96% under reaction conditions of free fatty acids:methanol molar ratio of 1:6.126, 55 °C, 2.261 wt.% catalyst and 2 h [44]. Despite being much milder conditions than those observed in heterogeneous catalysis, homogeneous catalysis is associated with several disadvantages such as reactor corrosion and the difficulty of separation the final product [4]. Huang et al. used mild conditions in its esterification reaction of oleic acid with a sulfated iron oxide catalyst (oleic acid:methanol molar ratio of 1:4, 100 °C, 10 wt.% catalyst and 2 h), but obtained a value of conversion rate of only 63.56% [42]. Kaur et al. used more drastic conditions in the esterification of nonanoic acid with a sulfated iron oxide catalyst (nonanoic acid:methanol molar ratio of of 1:10, reflux temperature, 4 g.L −1 of catalyst and 6 h) and obtained a conversion value of 83.4% [11]. The present work, in addition to having been reached conversion values of up to 100%, it presents the great advantage of using tailings as iron oxide sources, while other works in literature use commercial iron oxides. The obtained results are also comparable with them of other diverse heterogeneous catalysts found in the literature. Santos et al. prepared a catalyst for the esterification of oleic acid from oilseed cake by a sulfonation with concentrated H2SO4. The reaction using oleic acid:methanol molar ratio of 1:12, 60 °C, 20 wt.% catalyst and 2 h obtained a conversion value of 94% [8]. Vieira et al. used pure lanthanum oxide (LO), sulfated lanthanum oxide (SLO) and HZSM-5 impregnated with sulfated lanthanum oxide (SLO/HZSM-5) in esterification reaction of oleic acid. In optimized reaction conditions (acid:methanol molar ratio of 1:5, 100 °C, 10 wt.% catalyst and 7 h) the conversions were 67%, 96% and 100% for LO, SLO and SLO/HZSM-5, respectively [10]. Table 2 shows some more heterogeneous catalysts used in oleic acid esterification reactions, the conditions used in the reactions and the conversion values. The reactivity of the active sites of the catalysts was investigated in terms of turnover number (TON). The TONs calculates were 1440 molOA molsites −1, 88,050 molOA molsites −1 and 580 molOA molsites −1 for the catalysts DS, WS and AS, respectively. In addition, reproducibility tests were performed for the optimized reactions, and the error obtained was less than 5%. Results of atomic absorption showed that the main composition of the waste are iron species. In order to study a possible catalytic effect of the silica surface, a very simple and preliminary experiment leaching all the Fe oxide of the waste with concentrated HCl was carried out. The obtained pure silica was submitted to the same sulfatation process with H2SO4 and tested as catalyst for the esterification of oleic acid with methanol but showed no significant conversion indicating that all the catalytic activity observed is related to Fe oxide sulfated surface. According to the literature, silica can have different influences on the activity of materials, but there are no reports that silica can be sulfated at the same conditions used in this work. Duan et al. studied the esterification of octanoic acid with methanol using SiO2 doped sulfated aluminum-based solid acid as catalyst. The results demonstrated that the doping of the material with SiO2 resulted in the increase of surface areas and consequently the increase of the amount of surface sulfur species which led to an increase of acid sites, which consequently boosted the catalytic esterification activity [45]. Kuwahara et al. studied the esterification of levulinic acid with ethanol over sulfated Si-doped ZrO2 solid acid catalyst. The results demonstrated that incorporation of moderate amount of Si (up to 30 mol% Si per Zr) into sulfated ZrO2 greatly improves its surface area, and accordingly results in increased numbers of sulfate anions and the associated acid sites [46]. 3.3 Leaching and reuse tests The leaching tests were performed following the reaction conditions indicated in Table 1. These tests were carried out exposing the catalysts to methanol at 120 °C for 8 h followed by filtration and reaction of the methanol fraction containing leached acid with oleic acid. This reaction was called “homogeneous contribution”. Fig. 9 shows the conversion results of the esterification reactions performed with the methanol fractions containing the materials leached from the catalysts. The obtained results showed that the homogeneous contribution, i.e. acid leached from the solid catalysts, were similar for all catalysts ca. 20–27%. The literature data indicated that sulfated metal oxides are easily deactivated due to sulfate groups leaching. Possibly this deactivation occurs frequently because surface sulfur species can be easily modified by the presence of free water in reactions in aqueous solutions, forming H2SO4, HSO4 − and SO4 2-, leading to the loss of these active sites on the catalyst surface [10]. The reuse tests were also carried out under the best reaction conditions obtained for each catalyst (Fig. 10 ), according to Table 1. It was observed a great deactivation of DS and WS materials, which presented conversion in the second use of 26% and 18%, respectively. The AS material presented a conversion value of 60% for reuse reaction, and it was the catalyst less deactivated. The catalysts deactivation based on sulfated metals is a common problem that has been observed in several works, and it is related to the ease leaching of sulfate molecules [10]. 3.4 Comparisons between the materials produced The characterization techniques did not show significant structural changes between the produced materials by the different processes and neither between the untreated waste. The differences observed are related only to the calcination process. However, elements mapping showed the presence of sulfur in the catalysts produced. Potentiometric titration and infrared spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption techniques indicated a great increase in the acidity of the materials produced due to sulfate groups presence. Although no structural differences were observed in the materials produced by different synthesis, the results obtained by potentiometric titration showed that materials produced with sulfuric acid solution presented much stronger acid sites and higher acid density when compared with materials produced by other syntheses, indicating that these materials have potential to present greater catalytic activity. The catalytic tests clearly showed better results for the materials produced by acidic synthesis with sulfuric acid (AS), followed by the materials produced by dry synthesis with ammonium sulfate and, finally, the materials produced by wet synthesis with ammonium sulfate solution. As there was no evidence of structural changes in relation to the catalysts produced and the precursor waste, it is believed that the main difference in the activity of the AS catalyst in relation to the others is due to a higher concentration of sulfate groups on the catalyst surface. The AS material was produced by a impregnation with sulfuric acid solution, and it is believed that, due to the strongly acidic medium, there was a strong attack on the material surface, leading to the leaching of a part of the iron in the waste structure. When the material was dried, the leaching iron ions was impregnated together with the sulfate groups on the surface of the material based in silica and iron oxides. In the calcination process, the impregnated iron formed a well dispersed sulfated hematite phase on the material surface. This great dispersion is related to the fact that it has undergone a solubilization phase, followed by impregnation and calcination. Fig. 11 shows a scheme of the proposed mechanism for acidic synthesis. The DS material was produced by a dry synthesis with ammonium sulfate, so the iron leaching and impregnation process did not occur. However, the energy from the maceration process may have favored superficial reactions between the ammonium sulfate and the superficial iron of the reject, leading to the formation of active phases. Already, the WS material was produced by a wet synthesis with ammonium sulfate solution, and possibly no iron leaching occurred because the medium presented low acidity. In addition, the reaction between the iron reject surface and the sulfate groups should not be as effective because the activation process did not occur. It is then believed that during the impregnation a sulfate layer was formed on the surface of the material, however on a smaller scale than that observed for the materials produced by the other processes. To confirm these facts, a test was made in which all the syntheses were redone and, before the calcination process, the materials were washed with distilled water. The wash water was analyzed by atomic absorption for iron quantification. The results obtained for the amount of iron in the solution were 1.04 mg.L−1 for the dry synthesis, 0.14 mg.L−1 for the wet synthesis and 278.88 mg.L−1 for the acidic synthesis. These values indicate that there was a much stronger attack and a much greater solubilization of the iron, that will be formed high dispersed iron sulfate groups after calcination, in the acidic synthesis, followed by the dry synthesis and, finally, the wet synthesis, which corroborates what was discussed previously. 4 Conclusions Based on the experimental data obtained for the materials activities, it can be concluded that low-cost acid heterogeneous catalysts were produced from iron ore tailings and the catalysts were efficient and promising in the esterification reactions of oleic acid and methanol. The catalysts were prepared by three different processes, i.e. ammonium sulfate by simple grinding, (NH4)2SO4 aqueous impregnation and sulfuric acid solution, all treated at 550 °C. Characterization techniques and catalytic tests indicated that synthesis with sulfuric acid was the most efficient process due to the formation of a greater amount of dispersed acid sites. Methyl oleate production using 5 wt% of catalyst based on acid synthesis, 1:15 oleic acid:methanol molar ratio, 120 °C and 4 h led to conversions of 100%. coredata.dc:description: In this work, heterogeneous acid catalysts based on sulfated iron oxide produced from mining tailings were prepared by different processes, i.e. ammonium sulfate by simple grinding, (NH4)2SO4 aqueous impregnation and sulfuric acid impregnation, all treated at 500 °C. The materials were characterized by Mössbauer and Raman spectroscopies, FTIR, XRD, SEM, pyridine adsorption FTIR and potentiometric titration. The main mineral phases found were hematite and quartz and it was observed a great increase in the acidity of the materials produced due to the presence of sulfate groups. The synthesis with sulfuric acid was the most efficient process due to the formation of a greater amount of dispersed acid sites (density 0.1211 mmol g−1). The materials were used in esterification reactions. Ester production using 5 wt% of catalyst based on acid synthesis, 1:15 oleic acid:methanol molar ratio, 120 °C and 4 h led to conversions of 100%.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous acid catalyst based on sulfated iron ore tailings for oleic acid esterification
